words.def: tumor, usually benign, which may develop on the hearing and balance nerves and can cause gradual hearing loss, tinnitus, and/or dizziness. (sometimes called vestibular schwannoma). Also see Neurofibromatosis Type 2.
words.name: Acoustic neuroma

words.def: loss of hearing that occurs or develops some time during the lifespan but is not present at birth.
words.name: Acquired deafness

words.def: loss of the sense of taste.
words.name: Ageusia

words.def: hereditary condition characterized by kidney disease, sensorineural hearing loss, and sometimes eye defects.
words.name: Alport syndrome

words.def: manual language with its own syntax and grammar, used primarily by people who are deaf.
words.name: American Sign Language (ASL)

words.def: total or partial loss of the ability to use or understand language; usually caused by stroke, brain disease, or injury.
words.name: Aphasia

words.def: complete loss of voice.
words.name: Aphonia

words.def: inability to execute a voluntary movement despite being able to demonstrate normal muscle function.
words.name: Apraxia

words.def: inability to correctly produce speech sounds (phonemes) because of imprecise placement, timing, pressure, speed, or flow of movement of the lips, tongue, or throat.
words.name: Articulation disorder

words.def: technical tools and devices such as alphabet boards, text telephones, or text-to-speech conversion software used to aid individuals who have communication disorders perform actions, tasks, and activities.
words.name: Assistive devices

words.def: health care professional who is trained to evaluate hearing loss and related disorders, including balance (vestibular) disorders and tinnitus, and to rehabilitate individuals with hearing loss and related disorders. An audiologist uses a variety of tests and procedures to assess hearing and balance function and to fit and dispense hearing aids and other assistive devices for hearing.
words.name: Audiologist

words.def: a test for brain functioning in comatose, unresponsive, etc., patients, and for hearing in infants and young children; involves attaching electrodes to the head to record electrical activity from the hearing nerve and other parts of the brain.
words.name: Auditory Brainstem Response test (ABR test)

words.def: eighth cranial nerve that connects the inner ear to the brainstem and is responsible for hearing and balance.
words.name: Auditory nerve

words.def: ability to identify, interpret, and attach meaning to sound.
words.name: Auditory perception

words.def: device that substitutes or enhances the ability to hear.
words.name: Auditory prosthesis

words.def: tools that help individuals with limited or absent speech to communicate, such as communication boards, pictographs (symbols that look like the things they represent), or ideographs (symbols representing ideas).
words.name: Augmentative devices

words.def: techniques used with people who are hearing impaired to improve their ability to speak and communicate.
words.name: Aural rehabilitation

words.def: individual's immune system produces abnormal antibodies that react against the body's healthy tissues.
words.name: Autoimmune deafness

words.def: can refer to autistic disorder a psychiatric syndrome featuring restricted and repetitive behaviors, and impaired social interaction and communication; or the group of syndromes to which autistic disorder belongs - the autism spectrum disorders.
words.name: Autism

words.def: Prelinguistic sound play by infants; characterized by labial consonants(/b/p/m/).
words.name: Babbling

words.def: biological system that enables individuals to know where their bodies are in the environment and to maintain a desired position. Normal balance depends on information from the labyrinth in the inner ear, from other senses such as sight and touch, and from muscle movement.
words.name: Balance

words.def: disruption in the labyrinth, the inner ear organ that controls the balance system, which allows individuals to know where their bodies are in the environment. The labyrinth works with other systems in the body, such as the visual and skeletal systems, to maintain posture.
words.name: Balance disorder

words.def: injury to the middle ear caused by a reduction of air pressure.
words.name: Barotrauma

words.def: balance disorder that results in sudden onset of dizziness, spinning, or vertigo when moving the head.
words.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)

words.def: auditory prosthesis that bypasses the cochlea and auditory nerve. This type of implant helps individuals who cannot benefit from a cochlear implant because the auditory nerves are not working.
words.name: Brainstem implant

words.def: text display of spoken words, presented on a television or a movie screen, that allows a deaf or hard-of-hearing viewer to follow the dialogue and the action of a program simultaneously.
words.name: Captioning

words.def: inability to differentiate, recognize, or understand sounds; hearing and intelligence are normal.
words.name: Central auditory processing disorder

words.def: diseases or problems associated with the sense of smell or the sense of taste.
words.name: Chemosensory disorders

words.def: accumulation of dead cells in the middle ear, caused by repeated middle ear infections.
words.name: Cholesteatoma

words.def: snail-shaped structure in the inner ear that contains the organ of hearing.
words.name: Cochlea

words.def: medical device that bypasses damaged structures in the inner ear and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing some deaf individuals to learn to hear and interpret sounds and speech.
words.name: Cochlear implant

words.def: thinking skills that include perception, memory, awareness, reasoning, judgment, intellect, and imagination.
words.name: Cognition

words.def: hearing loss caused by dysfunction of the outer or middle ear.
words.name: Conductive hearing impairment

words.def: method of communication that combines speech reading with a system of handshapes placed near the mouth to help deaf or hard-of-hearing individuals differentiate words that look similar on the lips (e.g., bunch vs. punch) or are hidden (e.g., gag).
words.name: Cued speech

words.def: one group of herpes viruses that infects humans and can cause a variety of clinical symptoms, including deafness or hearing impairment; infection with the virus may be either before or after birth.
words.name: Cytomegalovirus (Congenital)

words.def: unit that measures the intensity or loudness of sound.
words.name: Decibel

words.def: in individuals with normal muscle tone and speech muscle coordination, partial loss of the ability to consistently pronounce words.
words.name: Developmental verbal dyspraxia

words.def: physical unsteadiness, imbalance, and lightheadedness associated with balance disorders.
words.name: Dizziness

words.def: group of speech disorders caused by disturbances in the strength or coordination of the muscles of the speech mechanism as a result of damage to the brain or nerves.
words.name: Dysarthria

words.def: any disturbance of balance.
words.name: Dysequilibrium

words.def: disruption in the smooth flow or expression of speech.
words.name: Dysfluency

words.def: distortion or absence of the sense of taste.
words.name: Dysgeusia

words.def: learning disability characterized by reading difficulties. Some individuals may also have difficulty writing, spelling, or working with numbers.
words.name: Dyslexia

words.def: distortion or absence of the sense of smell.
words.name: Dysosmia

words.def: difficulty swallowing.
words.name: Dysphagia

words.def: any impairment of the voice or speaking ability.
words.name: Dysphonia

words.def: abnormal muscle tone of one or more muscles.
words.name: Dystonia

words.def: presence and growth of bacteria or viruses in the ear.
words.name: Ear infection

words.def: yellow secretion from glands in the outer ear (cerumen) that keeps the skin of the ear dry and protected from infection.
words.name: Earwax

words.def: Repeating what one has already said or heard; often associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder.
words.name: Echolalia

words.def: fluid in the labyrinth (the organ of balance located in the inner ear that consists of three semicircular canals and the vestibule).
words.name: Endolymph

words.def: System of rules used by speakers of a language to produce and understand spoken language.
words.name: Grammar

words.def: act or sensation of tasting.
words.name: Gustation

words.def: disease related to eyes due to increase in IOP(intraorbicular pressure)
words.name: Glaucoma

words.def: sensory cells of the inner ear, which are topped with hair-like structures, the stereocilia, and which transform the mechanical energy of sound waves into nerve impulses.
words.name: Hair cells

words.def: sense of physical contact or touch.
words.name: Haptic sense

words.def: instrument for measuring sensitivity to touch.
words.name: Haptometer

words.def: series of events in which sound waves in the air are converted to electrical signals, which are sent as nerve impulses to the brain, where they are interpreted.
words.name: Hearing

words.def: electronic device that brings amplified sound to the ear. A hearing aid usually consists of a microphone, amplifier, and receiver.
words.name: Hearing aid

words.def: disruption in the normal hearing process that may occur in outer, middle, or inner ear, whereby sound waves are not conducted to the inner ear, converted to electrical signals and/or nerve impulses are not transmitted to the brain to be interpreted.
words.name: Hearing disorder

words.def: hearing loss passed down through generations of a family.
words.name: Hereditary hearing impairment

words.def: abnormally rough or harsh-sounding voice caused by vocal abuse and other disorders such as gastroesophageal reflux, thyroid problems, or trauma to the larynx (voice box).
words.name: Hoarseness

words.def: the hiccups
words.name: Hyper neurotic diafragma contractions

words.def: diminished sensitivity to taste.
words.name: Hypogeusia

words.def: diminished sensitivity to smell.
words.name: Hyposmia

words.def: Alterations in the pitch and prosody of spoken language to convey meaning.
words.name: Inflection

words.def: part of the ear that contains both the organ of hearing (the cochlea) and the organ of balance (the labyrinth).
words.name: Inner ear

words.def: Refers to the energy flow per unit area (audiology).
words.name: Intensity

words.def: disorder that can include several characteristics such as absence of the sense of smell and decreased functional activity of the gonads (organs that produce sex cells), affecting growth and sexual development.
words.name: Kallmann's syndrome

words.def: organ of balance located in the inner ear. The labyrinth consists of three semicircular canals and the vestibule.
words.name: Labyrinth

words.def: excessive fluid in the organ of balance (labyrinth); can cause pressure or fullness in the ears, hearing loss, dizziness, and loss of balance.
words.name: Labyrinthine hydrops

words.def: viral or bacterial infection or inflammation of the inner ear that can cause dizziness, loss of balance, and temporary hearing loss.
words.name: Labyrinthitis

words.def: childhood disorder of unknown origin which often extends into adulthood and can be identified by gradual or sudden loss of the ability to understand and use spoken language.
words.name: Landau-Kleffner syndrome

words.def: system for communicating ideas and feelings using sounds, gestures, signs, or marks.
words.name: Language

words.def: any of a number of problems with verbal communication and the ability to use or understand a symbol system for communication.
words.name: Language disorders

words.def: abnormal growths in the larynx (voice box) that can be cancerous or noncancerous.
words.name: Laryngeal neoplasms

words.def: noncancerous, callous-like growths on the inner parts of the vocal folds (vocal cords); usually caused by vocal abuse or misuse.
words.name: Laryngeal nodules

words.def: loss of function or feeling of one or both of the vocal folds caused by injury or disease to the nerves of the larynx.
words.name: Laryngeal paralysis

words.def: surgery to remove part or all of the larynx (voice box).
words.name: Laryngectomy

words.def: hoarse voice or the complete loss of the voice because of irritation to the vocal folds (vocal cords).
words.name: Laryngitis

words.def: laryngeal framework surgery of a paralysed vocal cord to help strengthen the voice - a window in the thyroid cartilage is created and an implant is inserted into the para-glottic space via an open approach.
words.name: Laryngoplasty

words.def: valve structure between the trachea (windpipe) and the pharynx (the upper throat) that is the primary organ of voice production.
words.name: Larynx

words.def: childhood disorders characterized by difficulty with certain skills such as reading or writing in individuals with normal intelligence.
words.name: Learning disabilities

words.def: back portion of the temporal bone that contains the inner ear.
words.name: Mastoid

words.def: surgical procedure to remove infection from the mastoid bone.
words.name: Mastoid surgery

words.def: movement disorder that can involve excessive eye blinking (blepharospasm) with involuntary movements of the jaw muscles, lips, and tongue (oromandibular dystonia).
words.name: Meige syndrome

words.def: inner ear disorder that can affect both hearing and balance. It can cause episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and the sensation of fullness in the ear.
words.name: Ménière's disease

words.def: inflammation of the meninges, the membranes that envelop the brain and the spinal cord; may cause hearing loss or deafness.
words.name: Meningitis

words.def: part of the ear that includes the eardrum and three tiny bones of the middle ear, ending at the round window that leads to the inner ear.
words.name: Middle ear

words.def: inaccurately produced speech sound (phoneme) or sounds.
words.name: Misarticulation

words.def: group of disorders caused by the inability to accurately produce speech sounds (phonemes) because of muscle weakness or incoordination or difficulty performing voluntary muscle movements.
words.name: Motor speech disorders

words.def: ability of the brain and/or certain parts of the nervous system to adapt to new conditions, such as an injury.
words.name: Neuroplasticity

words.def: devices that substitute for an injured or diseased part of the nervous system, such as the cochlear implant.
words.name: Neural prostheses

words.def: to activate or energize a nerve through an external source.
words.name: Neural stimulation

words.def: group of inherited disorders in which noncancerous tumors grow on several nerves that may include the hearing nerve. The symptoms of NF-1 include coffee-colored spots on the skin, enlargement, deformation of bones, and neurofibromas.
words.name: Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1 von Recklinghausen's)

words.def: group of inherited disorders in which noncancerous tumors grow on several nerves that usually include the hearing nerve. The symptoms of NF-2 include tumors on the hearing nerve which can affect hearing and balance. NF-2 may occur in the teenage years with hearing loss. Also see acoustic neurinoma.
words.name: Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF-2)

words.def: inability to exchange information with others because of hearing, speech, and/or language problems caused by impairment of the nervous system (brain or nerves).
words.name: Neurogenic communication disorder

words.def: hearing loss caused by exposure to harmful sounds, either very loud impulse sound(s) or repeated exposure to sounds over 90-decibel level over an extended period of time that damage the sensitive structures of the inner ear.
words.name: Noise-induced hearing loss

words.def: hearing loss or deafness that is inherited and is not associated with other inherited clinical characteristics.
words.name: Nonsyndromic hereditary hearing impairment

words.def: substance that stimulates the sense of smell.
words.name: Odorant

words.def: the act of smelling.
words.name: Olfaction

words.def: device for estimating the intensity of the sense of smell.
words.name: Olfactometer

words.def: understanding speech without visual clues (speech reading).
words.name: Open-set speech recognition

words.def: inflammation of the outer part of the ear extending to the auditory canal.
words.name: Otitis externa

words.def: inflammation of the middle ear caused by infection.
words.name: Otitis media

words.def: low-intensity sounds produced by the inner ear that can be quickly measured with a sensitive microphone placed in the ear canal.
words.name: Otoacoustic emissions

words.def: physician/surgeon who specializes in diseases of the ears, nose, throat, and head and neck.
words.name: Otolaryngologist

words.def: physician/surgeon who specializes in diseases of the ear.
words.name: Otologist

words.def: abnormal growth of bone of the inner ear. This bone prevents structures within the ear from working properly and causes hearing loss. For some people with otosclerosis, the hearing loss may become severe.
words.name: Otosclerosis

words.def: drugs such as a special class of antibiotics, aminoglycoside antibiotics, that can damage the hearing and balance organs located in the inner ear for some individuals.
words.name: Ototoxic drugs

words.def: external portion of the ear, consisting of the pinna, or auricle, and the ear canal.
words.name: Outer ear

words.def: group of viruses that can cause noncancerous wart-like tumors to grow on the surface of skin and internal organs such as the respiratory tract; can be life-threatening.
words.name: Papillomavirus

words.def: any disease or perversion of the sense of smell, especially the subjective perception of odors that do not exist.
words.name: Parosmia

words.def: process of knowing or being aware of information through the ear.
words.name: Perception (Hearing)

words.def: leakage of inner ear fluid to the middle ear that occurs without apparent cause or that is associated with head trauma, physical exertion, or barotrauma.
words.name: Perilymph fistula

words.def: disorders characterized by delays in several areas of development that may include socialization and communication.
words.name: Pervasive developmental disorders

words.def: chemical substances secreted by an animal that elicit a specific behavioral or physiological response in another animal of the same species.
words.name: Pheromones

words.def: study of speech sounds.
words.name: Phonology

words.def: individual who becomes deaf after having acquired language.
words.name: Postlingually deafened

words.def: individual who is either born deaf or who lost his or her hearing early in childhood, before acquiring language.
words.name: Prelingually deafened

words.def: loss of hearing that gradually occurs because of changes in the inner or middle ear in individuals as they grow older.
words.name: Presbycusis

words.def: any of a group of problems characterized by difficulty using or understanding the symbol system for written language.
words.name: Reading disorders

words.def: membrane separating the middle ear and inner ear.
words.name: Round window

words.def: hearing loss caused by damage to the sensory cells and/or nerve fibers of the inner ear.
words.name: Sensorineural hearing loss

words.def: method of communication for people who are deaf or hard of hearing in which hand movements, gestures, and facial expressions convey grammatical structure and meaning. rhinitis.
words.name: Sign language

words.def: ability to produce voice.
words.name: Sound vocalization

words.def: momentary disruption of voice caused by involuntary movements of one or more muscles of the larynx or voice box.
words.name: Spasmodic dysphonia

words.def: difficulty with language or the organized-symbol system used for communication in the absence of problems such as mental retardation, hearing loss, or emotional disorders.
words.name: Specific language impairment (SLI)

words.def: spoken communication.
words.name: Speech

words.def: any defect or abnormality that prevents an individual from communicating by means of spoken words. Speech disorders may develop from nerve injury to the brain, muscular paralysis, structural defects, hysteria, or mental retardation.
words.name: Speech disorder

words.def: part of a cochlear implant that converts speech sounds into electrical impulses to stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing an individual to understand sound and speech.
words.name: Speech processor

words.def: health professional trained to evaluate and treat people who have voice, speech, language, or swallowing disorders (including hearing impairment) that affect their ability to communicate.
words.name: Speech-language pathologist

words.def: also known as a cerebrovascular accident (CVA); caused by a lack of blood to the brain, resulting in the sudden loss of speech, language, or the ability to move a body part, and, if severe enough, death.
words.name: Stroke

words.def: frequent repetition of words or parts of words that disrupts the smooth flow of speech.
words.name: Stuttering

words.def: loss of hearing that occurs quickly due to such causes as explosion, a viral infection, or the use of some drugs.
words.name: Sudden deafness

words.def: any of a group of problems that interferes with the transfer of food from the mouth to the stomach.
words.name: Swallowing disorders

words.def: hearing loss or deafness that, along with other characteristics, is inherited or passed down through generations of a family.
words.name: Syndromic hearing impairment

words.def: related to touch or the sense of touch.
words.name: Tactile

words.def: mechanical instruments that make use of touch to help individuals who have certain disabilities, such as deaf-blindness, to communicate.
words.name: Tactile devices

words.def: disorders or diseases of the larynx (voice box), pharynx, or esophagus.
words.name: Throat disorders

words.def: surgical technique(s) to improve the human voice by altering single or multiple structures of the larynx, which houses the vocal folds (vocal cords) with the related controlling nerves, muscles, and cartilage. Typically, this surgery is considered to improve the position or tension of the vocal folds which can improve vocal volume and production. This is also known as laryngeal framework surgery. The most common technique may be to insert small blocks of custom-shaped silastin just inside of the tracheal wall, pushing the vocal fold muscle inward (medialization). This typically strengthens the output of a weaker voice but it also reduces the exchange volume of pulmonary function, as the tracheal opening has been permanently reduced. This surgery is named for its proximity to the thyroid gland.
words.name: Thyroplasty

words.def: sensation of a ringing, roaring, or buzzing sound in the ears or head. It is often associated with many forms of hearing impairment. Noise exposure and inner ear infections are but two predisposing conditions which can lead to the development of tinnitus.
words.name: Tinnitus

words.def: large muscle on the floor of the mouth that manipulates food for chewing and swallowing. It is the main organ of taste, and assists in forming speech sounds.
words.name: Tongue

words.def: tactile sense; the sense by which contact with the skin or mucous membrane is experienced.
words.name: Touch

words.def: neurological disorder characterized by recurring movements and sounds (called tics).
words.name: Tourette syndrome

words.def: surgical opening into the trachea (windpipe) to help someone breathe who has an obstruction or swelling in the larynx (voice box) or upper throat or who has had the larynx surgically removed.
words.name: Tracheostomy

words.def: Hereditary disease with multiorgan manifestation. Typical symptoms are epileptic seizures, autism, skin disorders, and renal tumors.
words.name: Tuberous Sclerosis

words.def: surgical repair of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) or bones of the middle ear.
words.name: Tympanoplasty

words.def: Taste of substances such as L-glutamate salts (MSG) that are found in foods like bouillon and other stocks. (reference:Yamaguchi S, Ninomiya K. J Nutr. 2000 Apr:130(4S Suppl):921S-926S.)
words.name: Umami

words.def: hereditary disease that affects hearing and vision and sometimes balance.
words.name: Usher syndrome

words.def: Long bone in the arm on the pinky side that goes from the humerus to the carpal.
words.name: Ulna

words.def: inherited disorder characterized by cleft palate (opening in the roof of the mouth), heart defects, characteristic facial appearance, minor learning problems, and speech and feeding problems.
words.name: Velocardiofacial syndrome

words.def: illusion of movement; a sensation as if the external world were revolving around an individual (objective vertigo) or as if the individual were revolving in space (subjective vertigo).
words.name: Vertigo

words.def: infection at the vestibular nerve.
words.name: Vestibular Neuronitis

words.def: system in the body that is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and the body's orientation in space. This system also regulates locomotion and other movements and keeps objects in visual focus as the body moves.
words.name: Vestibular system

words.def: bony cavity of the inner ear.
words.name: Vestibule

words.def: mechanical instruments that help individuals who are deaf to detect and interpret sound through the sense of touch.
words.name: Vibrotactile aids

words.def: inability of one or both vocal folds (vocal cords) to move because of damage to the brain or nerves.
words.name: Vocal cord paralysis

words.def: muscularized folds of mucous membrane that extend from the larynx (voice box) wall. The folds are enclosed in elastic vocal ligament and muscle that control the tension and rate of vibration of the cords as air passes through them.
words.name: Vocal cords (Vocal folds)

words.def: see Vocal cords.
words.name: Vocal folds

words.def: trembling or shaking of one or more of the muscles of the larynx, resulting in an unsteady-sounding voice.
words.name: Vocal tremor

words.def: sound produced by air passing out through the larynx and upper respiratory tract.
words.name: Voice

words.def: group of problems involving abnormal pitch, loudness, or quality of the sound produced by the larynx (voice box).
words.name: Voice disorders

words.def: hereditary disorder that is characterized by hearing impairment, a white shock of hair and/or distinctive blue color to one or both eyes, and wide-set inner corners of the eyes. Balance problems are also associated with some types of Waardenburg syndrome.
words.name: Waardenburg syndrome
